metadata.title: Effect of morphology of carbon nanomaterials on thermo-physical characteristics, optical properties and photo-thermal conversion performance of nanofluids

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Renewable Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/renene
Effect of morphology of carbon nanomaterials on thermo-physical characteristics, optical properties and photo-thermal conversion performance of nanofluids
Long Zhang, Leilei Chen, Jian Liu, Xiaoming Fang*, Zhengguo Zhang**
Key Laboratory of Enhanced Heat Transfer and Energy Conservation, The Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510640, China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 14 August 2015 Received in revised form 6 December 2015 Accepted 27 July 2016
Keywords: Nanofluid Direct absorption solar collector Carbon nanomaterials Radiative property Photothermal conversion performance
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: cexmfang@scut.edu.cn (X. (Z. Zhang).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2016.07.073 0960-1481/© 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
a b s t r a c t
Graphite nanoparticles (GNPs), single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and graphene (GE) were dispersed into an ionic liquid (IL) to prepare nanofluids at different mass fractions, respectively. The thermo-physical characteristics, radiative properties, and photo-thermal conversion performance of the IL-based nanofluids containing the carbon nanomaterials with different morphologies were investigated in details. It is shown that all the nanofluids exhibit an increase in thermal conductivity and a decrease in viscosity as composed with the base liquid, and the enhancement and reduction ratios varied with their morphologies. The GE-dispersed nanofluids exhibit the highest thermal conductivity enhancement ratios as compared to the GNPs- and SWCNTs-dispersed ones at the same mass fractions. Among the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials, the GE-dispersed nanofluids show the lowest transmittance and possess the highest extinction coefficients. It is revealed that the photo-thermal conversion performance of the IL has been enhanced by the addition of the carbon nanomterials, and the GE-dispersed nanofluids exhibit the highest photo-thermal conversion efficiency among the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials. The superiorities in thermal conductivity, optical property and photothermal conversion efficiency make the GE-dispersed nanofluids show great potential for use as highperformance HTFs in solar thermal systems such as working fluids for DASCs.
© 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Dispersing a little amount of nanomaterials including metallic or oxide nanoparticles or carbon nanomaterials into conventional heat transfer fluids (HTFs) such as water, thermal oil, etc., has been proved to be one of the effective routes for heat transfer enhancement [1e4]. This kind of suspensions consisting of base liquids and nanomaterials is named as nanofluid, which term was coined by Choi in 1995 [5]. It has been reported that nanofluids exhibited increased thermo-physical properties especially in thermal conductivity [6e8] and enhanced heat transfer coefficients [2e4,9,10], compared to their corresponding base liquids. Moreover, when nanofluids are used as HTFs, the clogging phenomenon
Fang), cezhang@scut.edu.cn
of pumps and pipes can be alleviated owing to the nanoscale of the additives [11]. All these advantages make nanofluids show great potentials for use as novel HTFs in many fields [12e16].
Direct absorption solar collectors (DASCs) is a promising type of novel solar collectors, which concept was proposed by Minardi et al., in 1975 [17]. Different from the commonly used surface-based solar collectors, DASCs, where working fluids directly absorb solar radiation, exhibit reduced heat loss by minimizing temperature differences between the absorber and the fluid, thus promising increased performance [17]. It is obvious that the working fluids that function as both the absorber and the transporter are critical for DASCs. However, the previously used working fluids for DASCs were black inks or solutions containing organic dyes, which suffered from low thermal conductivity and photo-induced instability. Consequently, the DASCs based on those working fluids didn't exhibit high performance as expected. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop novel working fluids with high thermal conductivity, excellent optical property along with good stability for DASCs.
Recently, nanofluids have attracted an increasingly interest for use as the working fluids for DASCs, which mainly focuses on theoretical prediction and experimental evaluation on efficiencies of the nanofluid-based DASCs [18e21] as well as investigations on radiative properties of the nanofluids [11,22e25]. The researchers from Arizona State University [26,27] reported that a theoretical nanofluid enhancement in efficiency of up to 10% could be achieved by the nanofluid-based DASCs as compared to surface-based collectors. Lenert et al. [28] presented that receiver-side efficiencies are predicted to exceed 35% when the nanofluid-based DASCs are coupled to a power cycle and optimized with respect to the optical thickness and solar exposure time. Taylor et al. [29] obtained extinction coefficients of the nanofluids by both model predictions and spectroscopic measurements and found that over 95% of incoming sunlight can be absorbed by the nanofluids with extremely low nanoparticle volume fractions. All these results show that, nanofluid-based DASCs promise high performance, and nanofluids possess increased extinction coefficients due to the absorption and scattering of the nanoadditives. In addition, nanofluids containing nanoadditives of metal, metallic oxide or carbon are expected to possess superior stability over those inks or solutions of organic dyes. Obviously, nanofluids can be considered as promising working fluids for DASCs. Note that nanofluids containing different kinds of nanomaterials exhibit different thermophysical and radiative properties. Furthermore, in view of the dual role of the nanofluids used in DASCs, it is rational that the thermo-physical and radiative properties of nanofluids determine their ability to convert light energy to heat, all of which are supposed to play a key role in establishing the collecting efficiency of the nanofluid-based DASCs [11]. Undoubtedly, the nanofluids with high thermo-physical and radiative properties as well as excellent photo-thermal conversion performance are highly desirable for high-efficiency DASCs.
Up to now, the nanomaterials used for preparing the nanofluids for DASCs mainly include the nanoparticles of Al, Au, Ag, Al2O3, TiO2, etc. [18,27,29,30], together with the carbon nanomaterials such as graphite nanoparticles [31], single- and multi-wall carbon nanotubes [23,32,33] and carbon nanohorns [34]. Among them, carbon nanomaterials are the most attractive nanoadditives due to their ultra-high thermal conductivity along with the black color suitable for optical absorption. The thermal conductivity of carbon nanomaterials (2000 W m 1 K 1 for graphite, 2000e6000Wm 1 K 1 for carbon nanotubes and 5000Wm 1 K 1 for graphene, etc.), is order of magnitude higher than that of the metallic or oxide nanomaterials such as aluminum (237 W m 1 K 1) and aluminum oxide (40 W m 1 K 1) [35]. Furthermore, our previous work [36] demonstrated that, when the pure and carbon-coated Ni nanoparticles with the same average sizes of 40 nmwere dispersed into the same base liquid at the same loading, respectively, the obtained nanofluid containing the carbon-coated Ni nanoparticles exhibited better radiative property than the un-coated Ni nanoparticles dispersed one, revealing that carbon coated on the surfaces of Ni nanoparticles enhanced the radiative property of the nanofluid containing them. Apparently, the thermal and optical superiority of carbon nanomaterials over metallic and oxide nanoparticles makes them show greater potential for use to prepare the nanofluids with high thermal conductivity and excellent radiative property for DASCs. Note that carbon nanomaterials are a family of carbon materials with numerous members showing different morphologies. Therefore, in order to exploit high-performance nanofluids for DASCs, it is necessary to conduct a systematical investigation on the effect of morphology of carbon nanomaterials on the thermo-physical and optical properties as well as the photo-thermal conversion performance of the nanofluids containing them.
In the current work, three kinds of carbon nanomaterials with different morphologies were chosen as the nanoadditives to prepare ionic liquid (IL)-based nanofluids suitable for mediumtemperature DASCs, which are zero-dimensional graphite nanoparticles (GNPs), one-dimensional single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and two-dimensional graphene (GE), respectively. The effect of morphology of the carbon nanomaterials on the thermophysical characteristics and optical properties of the obtained nanofluids has been investigated for the first time. Furthermore, the photo-thermal conversion performance of the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials has been evaluated. It is found that the GE-dispersed nanofluid exhibits superior thermal conductivity, radiative properties and photo-thermal conversion performance over those SWCNTs- and GNPs-dispersed ones, suggesting its great potential for use as the high-performance working fluid for DASCs.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: [BMIM]BF4 (CAS Number: 174501-65-6) was provided by Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China. GNPs, SWCNTs and GE were purchased from Nanjing XFNano Material Tech Co., Ltd., China. According the specifications provided by the manufacturer, the morphological characteristics of the three kinds of carbon nanomaterials are as follows. GNPs have an average size of less than 30 nm and a specific surface area of more than 600m2/g. For the SWCNTs, their average diameter is less than 2 nm, and lengths range from 5 to 30 mm; the specific surface area of the SWCNTs is between 500 and 700 m2/g. GE is a single layer nanoplatelet with the thickness about 0.8 nm and single layer ratio is about 80%, it has a dimension between 0.5 and 2 mm and a specific surface area between 500 and 1000 m2/g. Furthermore, the carbon nanomaterials were observed using a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Hitachi H-7650, Japan), and the obtained TEM images are shown in Fig. 1. The GNPs are almost spherical and have a narrow size distribution, except for several large particles, which are likely the aggregates of the primary particles. The SWCNTs tend to entanglewith one another due to their large aspect ratios. The GE nanosheets are transparent, suggesting that they are composed of few layers. It is obvious that the GNPs, SWCNTs and GE have different morphologies, which correspond to zero-, one-, and twodimensional nanomaterials, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of IL-based nanofluids
sections.text: Nanofluids were prepared via the two-step method by dispersing the carbon nanomaterials into the IL, respectively. Specifically, a certain amount of each carbon nanomaterial (GNPs, SWCNTs, and GE) was added into [BMIM]BF4, followed bymagnetic stirring for 15 min. The obtained suspensions were thoroughly dispersed for 1 h using an ultrasonic apparatus at 400 W (KQ400KDE, Kunshan of Jiangsu Equipment Company, China). Themass fractions of each material were set at 0.005% and 0.01%, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Thermal conductivity
sections.text:
Thermal conductivity of the samples was measured at the temperatures ranging from20 C to 145 C using a thermal constant analyzer (TPS2500, Hot Disk Inc., Sweden). In order to precisely control the temperature, a cyclic phenylmethyl silicone oil bath was applied. After every increase in temperature, the samples were
equilibrated for at least 10 min before tested. The measurement accuracy of the thermal conductivity was within ±3%. All the measurements were repeated three times to ascertain the accuracy of the experimental results.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Viscosity
sections.text:
Viscosities of the samples were measured by a viscometer (DV-I, Brookfield, USA) that has a specified accuracy of ±1.0% at a revolution rate of 100 RPM. Each sample fluid was measured at the temperatures ranging from 25 C to 150 C with the help of a thermal thermostatic magnetic stirrer equipped with phenylmethyl silicone oil. In order to precisely control the temperatures, a cyclic phenylmethyl silicone oil bath was applied. After every increase in temperature, the samples were equilibrated for at least 10 min before measurements.
2.3.3. Specific heat Specific heat of the samples was evaluated on a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC, Q20, TA Instruments, USA) by the sapphire method. The temperature was kept at 25 C for 5 min, and then ramped to 150 C at an increasing rate of 10 Cmin 1 followed by keeping for another 5min. Themeasurements were repeated for three times, and average values were calculated for use in this paper. The measurement accuracy of the thermal conductivity was within ±3%.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Transmission spectrum
sections.text: Room temperature transmission spectra of [BMIM]BF4 and all the [BMIM]BF4-based nanofluids were recorded in the wavelength range from 200 to 2500 nm with a double-beam UVeViseNIR spectrophotometer (PerkinElmer Lambda950) using a cuvette with an optical path length of 10mm. The effect of multiple reflections at the interfaces between air, glass and fluid is assumed to be negligible. Wavelength accuracy: ±0.02 nm, stray light 0.00007%T.

sections.heading: 2.3.5. Photo-thermal conversion performance
sections.text: An experimental setup for evaluating the photo-thermal conversion performance of the nanofluids was set up, as illustrated in Fig. 2. A 700 W solar simulator (Solaredge 700, PerfectLight Co., China) equipped with an AM1.5 optical filter was used as the radiative source. Its average radiative heat flux was measured using a power meter and thermopile detector (UV-A, Beijing Normal University, China), which the measurement accuracy of the radiative heat flux was within ±4%. A custom quartz glass static cylinder was made to hold the nanofluids, which was thermally insulated using the foam with low thermal conductivity. Temperature measurements were taken using the type-K thermocouple probes (XCK-14, Omega), and a data acquisition system (34970 A, Angilent) was used to record the temperatures of each thermocouple. The measurement accuracy of the temperature was within ±0.02 K. The thermocouple probes were calibrated using a temperaturecontrolled bath with a resolution of 0.01 K (C50P, HAAKE). All samples were tested under identical conditions.

sections.heading: 3.1. Thermo-physical properties of nanofluids containing carbon nanomaterials with different morphologies
3.1.1. Thermal conductivity
sections.text:
Fig. 3a shows the thermal conductivity of [BMIM]BF4 and the ILbased nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at the mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01% at 20 C. The thermal conductivity of pure IL at 20 C is measured to be 0.163 W m 1 K 1. Compared with the pure IL, all the nanofluids exhibit an increase in thermal conductivity to varying digresses. In order to make comparisons in thermal conductivity among these nanofluids, their thermal conductivity enhancement ratios have been calculated using (ke k0)/k0, where ke and k0 are the thermal conductivity values of the nanofluid and the pure IL, respectively. As listed in Table 1, the thermal conductivity enhancement ratio of the zero-
dimensional GNPs dispersed nanofluid is as low as 1.0% at the loading of 0.005%, and obviously rises up to 9.4% as the loading of GNPs is increased to 0.01%. For the one-dimensional SWCNTs dispersed nanofluid, its thermal conductivity enhancement ratio is
increased from 6.2% to 14.7% as the loading of SWCNTs is increased from 0.005% to 0.01%. The thermal conductivity enhancement ratio of the two-dimensional GE dispersed nanofluid is as high as 13.9% at the loading of 0.005%, and further rises up to 16.3% as the loading of GE is increased to 0.01%. It is indicated that the dispersion of different carbon nanomaterials into the IL plays a different role in enhancing the thermal conductivity of the IL, implying that the thermal conductivity of nanofluid can be optimized by selecting a suitable nanomaterial. Apparently, a high thermal conductivity enhancement ratio has been achieved by the GE-dispersed nanofluids even at a loading of as low as 0.005%, suggesting that GE is an excellent nanoadditive for preparing nanofluids with high thermal conductivity.
The reasons why the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials exhibit different thermal conductivity enhancement ratios could be stated as follows. First, note that the three carbon materials have different thermal conductivity. According to the information provided by themanufacture, the thermal conductivity values are about 2000 W m 1 K 1 for the GNPs, 4000 W m 1 K 1 for the SWCNTs, and 5000 W 1 K 1 for the GE, respectively. It is rational that the nanofluids containing the nanomaterials with higher thermal conductivity are expected to exhibit higher thermal conductivity enhancement ratios. Consequently, compared to the GNPs- and SWCNTs-dispersed ones, the GE-dispersed nanofluids exhibit the highest thermal conductivity enhancement ratios at the same loadings due to the highest thermal conductivity of GE among the three kinds of carbon nanomaterials. Second, Hamilton and Crosser model has been obtained from the modification of the Maxwell's model by introducing a shape factor (n) and is shown as follows.
ke k0
¼ kp þ ðn 1Þk0 ðn 1Þf kp k0
kp þ ðn 1Þk0 þ f kp k0
ðH C modelÞ
Where k0, kp, and ke are the thermal conductivity of base liquid, nanomaterial and suspension, respectively; F is the volume fraction of nanomaterial. According to this model, nanofluids containing nanomaterials with different morphologies should exhibit variable thermal conductivity enhancement ratios, because the nanomaterials with different morphologies possess different shape factor values. It has been reported that the nanofluid containing the nanomaterial with larger aspect ratio, such as CNTs, exhibited higher thermal conductivity enhancement ratio than the one containing spherical nanoparticles, since one-dimensional nanomaterials could easily form percolating networks that contribute to the anomalous thermal conductivity [37,38]. However, compared with GE, the SWCNTs tangle more easily, as shown in Fig. 1b the tangling would increase the thermal resistance at the interface between the IL and the SWCNTs, thus hindering the thermal transportation in the SWCNTs-dispersed nanofluids [8]. Consequently, the thermal conductivity enhancement ratios of the SWCNTs-dispersed nanofluids are higher than those of the GNPsdispersed ones, but lower than those of the GE-dispersed ones at the same loadings.
Fig. 3b shows the temperature dependence in thermal conductivity of [BMIM]BF4 and the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at the mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01%. Table 1 lists the thermal conductivity enhancement ratios of all the nanofluids at different temperatures. The thermal conductivity of those IL-based nanofluids linearly increases with temperature in the range from 20 C to 145 C, similar to the trend for the IL [BMIM] BF4 that its thermal conductivity increases from 0.163 to 0.184 W m 1 K 1. At the same temperatures, the thermal conductivity values of the nanofluids are invariably larger than those of [BMIM]BF4. Notably, the thermal conductivity of the 0.01% GEdispersed nanofluids is 0.213 W m 1 K 1 at 145 C, exhibiting an enhancement ratio of as high as 15.4%. The high thermal conductivity of the GE-dispersed nanofluids makes it show great potential to be used as advanced HTFs in mid-to high-temperature applications.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Viscosity
sections.text:
Fig. 4a shows the viscosity of [BMIM]BF4 and the IL-based nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at the mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01% at 25 C. The viscosity of [BMIM]BF4 is measured to be 84.6 cp at 25 C. Compared to the IL, all the nanofluids exhibit a reduction in viscosity to varying extents. Specifically, the reductions by 29.1% and 13.4% are achieved by the zero-dimensional GNPs dispersed nanofluids at the loadings of 0.005% and 0.01%, respectively. These results suggest that the viscosity of the GNPs-dispersed nanofluids first decreases by the addition of the GNPs at the loading of 0.005%, and then rises up as the mass fraction of the GNPs is increased to 0.01%. The onedimensional SWCNTs dispersed nanofluids exhibit the reductions by 35.4% and 9.9% in viscosity at the loadings of 0.005% and 0.01%, showing a similar trend to that for the GNPs-dispersed ones. Differently, reductions by 23.8% and 40.6% in viscosity are achieved by the two-dimensional GE dispersed nanofluids at the loadings of 0.005% and 0.01%, respectively, suggesting that the viscosity of the GE-dispersed nanofluids can be further decreased by increasing the mass fraction of GE. It is revealed that the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials exhibit different viscosity reduction ratios at the same mass fractions. The reduction in viscosity should be attributed to the lubrication originated from the carbon nanomaterials added into the nanofluids [39]. It is implied that the
morphology of the nanomaterials has an influence on the viscosity of the nanofluids. And the mass fraction of different carbon materials plays a different role in modulating the viscosity of the corresponding nanofluids. The reason for this may be attributed to the different interfacial interaction between each carbon nanomaterials and the base fluid [40]. Compared with GE, the GNPs and SWCNTs added in the IL are more likely to agglomerate and tangle as their mass fractions are further increased, which result in the reduction in their lubrication and thus increase the viscosity of the nanofluids at a higher loading. The reduction in viscosity with the increase in mass fraction makes the GE-dispersed nanofluids more promising for use as novel HTFs.
Fig. 4b shows the temperature dependence in viscosity of [BMIM]BF4 and the IL-based nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01%. As the temperature is increased from 25 C to 150 C, the viscosity of [BMIM] BF4 and all the nanofluid greatly decreases until it finally reaches a minimum of around 5 cp at 150 C. Obviously, although the IL and its nanofluids possess high viscosity at the temperatures below 80 C, the remarkable reduction in viscosity with temperature makes the IL and its nanofluids suitable for use as HTFs in mid-to high-temperature applications.
3.1.3. Specific heat Fig. 5a shows the specific heat of [BMIM]BF4 and the IL-based nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at the mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01% at 30 C. The specific heat of [BMIM] BF4 is measured to be 1.903 J g 1 K 1. Compared with the IL, all the nanofluids exhibit a decrease in specific heat. Specifically, a reduction by 4.8%,12.3% and 12.8% has been achieved for the GNPs-, SWCNTs-, and GE-dispersed nanofluids at their mass fractions of 0.005%, and accordingly further decrease to 8.3%, 13.3%, and 15.3% as their mass fractions are increased to 0.01%. It is revealed that the specific heat of the nanofluids containing the carbon nanomaterials is lower than that of the base liquid, which is similar to the results reported by Bridges et al. [41] that the specific heat of the [C4mim] [NTf2]-based nanofluids containing carbon black (0.5 wt%) decreased by about 30% as compared to the pure IL. However, Nieto de Castro et al. [42] reported an opposite trend that the specific heat of the nanofluid containing MWCNTs was higher than that of the base IL (i.e., [C4mim][PF6]) in the temperature range from room temperature to 115 C. Up to now, there has not been an exact theory for explaining this phenomenon yet. In our opinion, the reduction in specific heat of the nanofluids containing the carbon nanomaterials is mainly attributed to the fact that the specific heat of bulk carbon materials is around 0.71 J g 1 K 1 at room temperature, much lower than 1.903 J g 1 K 1 of the pure IL ([BMIM]BF4).
In addition, the reductions achieved by the GNPs-dispersed nanofluids are less than those achieved by the SWCNT- and GEdispersed ones, which may originate from the fact that the zerodimensional GNPs has higher thermal energy density than the two-dimensional GE and the one-dimensional SWCNTs.
Fig. 5b shows the temperature dependence in specific heat of [BMIM]BF4 and the IL-based nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01%. As the temperature is increased from 30 C to 140 C, the specific heat of [BMIM]BF4 and its nanofluids gradually increase with temperature first and then shows a light decline after the temperature is more than 140 C. This decline could be explained by the phasetransition behavior of the ionic liquid at the temperatures of above 140 C [43]. At the same temperatures, the specific heat values of these nanofluids are slightly lower than those of the base IL. Specifically, reductions by about 5%, 12%, and 13.5% in specific heat have been found for the GNPs-, SWCNTs-, and GE-dispersed nanofluids at their loadings of 0.005%, and accordingly deteriorates to about 8%, 14% and 16% as their loadings are increased to 0.01%, respectively. Although the reduction in specific heat has a negative impact on the heat storage capacity of the nanofluids, the remarkable increase in specific heat with temperature makes the IL and its nanofluids suitable for use in mid-to high-temperature applications.

sections.heading: 3.2. Radiative property of nanofluids containing carbon nanomaterials with different morphologies
sections.text:
Fig. 6a shows the room temperature transmission spectra of [BMIM]BF4 and the IL-based nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at the mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01%. It can be seen that the IL is almost transparent in the visible light range (400e800 nm). For the zero-dimensional GNPs dispersed nanofluids, their transmittance is measured to be 55% at the loading of 0.005% in the visible-light range, and further decreases to 20% as the loading of the GNPs is increased to 0.01%. The transmittance of the one-dimensional SWCNTs dispersed nanofluid is decreased from 13e20% to 3e5% in the visible-light range as the mass fraction of SWCNTs is increased from 0.005% to 0.01%. For the twodimensional GE dispersed nanofluids, the transmittance is as low as about 3% in the visible range at the loading of 0.005% and further decreases to zero as the mass fraction of GE is increased to 0.01%, meaning that the incident light has been totally absorbed by the GE-dispersed nanofluid. It is revealed that the dispersion of different carbon nanomaterials into the IL plays a different role in improving the optical absorption of the IL, implying that the optical absorption property of the IL-based nanofluids can be optimized by selecting a suitable nanomaterial. Obviously, the GE-dispersed nanofluids exhibit much lower transmittance than the GNPs- and SWCNTs-dispersed ones, suggesting that GE is an excellent nanoadditive for preparing the nanofluids with excellent optical absorption property. Therefore, the GE-dispersed nanofluids show a promising prospect for using as the absorbers in DASCs.
In order to further investigate the optical properties of the ILbased nanofluids containing the carbon nanomaterials, their extinction coefficients (Kel), which represent both their scattering and absorption properties, have been calculated from the spectral transmittance T(l) based on the Beer Lambert law (Eq. (1)):
TðlÞ ¼ e Kel;y (1)
where y is the optical path, i.e.10 mm. Fig. 6b shows the extinction coefficients of [BMIM]BF4 and the IL-based nanofuids containing different carbon nanomaterials at mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01%. It can be found that the extinction coefficient of the IL is very
small, which is only about 0.01 cm 1 in the visible-light range (400e800 nm). Significantly, the extinction coefficients of the nanofluids are increased by several orders of magnitude as compared with that of the pure IL, indicating the optical properties of the nanofluids have been greatly enhanced by the introduction of the carbon nanomaterials. Furthermore, among all the nanofluids, the GE-dispersed ones exhibit the highest extinction coefficients at the same mass fractions. An extinction coefficient of as high as around 10 cm 1 has been achieved by the 0.01 wt% GE-dispersed nanofluid, suggesting its great potential for use as the working fluids for DASCs.
Note that the optical properties of a multiphase system are extraordinarily complex, such as a nanofluid. There has been the Rayleigh scattering approximation model that is generally used to quantitatively evaluate the optical property of spherical nanoparticles dispersed suspensions. Among the three kinds of carbon nanomaterials, the SWCNTs and GE are not spherical nanoparticles. Consequently, herein the Rayleigh scattering approximation model is used to only provide a qualitative understanding of the dominant factor that affects the optical properties of the nanofuids containing the three kinds of carbon nanomaterials. According to this model, the extinction coefficient of a nanofluid is expected to be highly dependent upon the shape, mass fraction and optical property of
the nanoadditives along with the optical property of the base liquid [24]. Because the GNPs, SWCNTs and GE used in the current work are graphitized carbon materials, their optical properties are deemed to be identical and can be considered to be the same as that of the bulk graphite. Apparently, when the mass fractions of the carbon nanomaterials are identical, the optical property of the ILbased nanofluids is only related to the morphology of the carbon nanomaterials. Therefore, it can be inferred that the difference in optical property of the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials is attributed to their different morphologies. It has been also found that the morphology of materials played a role in affecting the interactions between the nanomaterials with optical waves and photons [44]. The investigations on the effect of morphology on the optical property of nanofluids reveal that twodimensional GE shows greater potential for use to prepare nanofluids with excellent optical absorption property over the zerodimensional GNPs and one-dimensional SWCNTs.

sections.heading: 3.3. Photo-thermal conversion performance of nanofluids containing carbon nanomaterials with different morphologies
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows the temperature enhancement as a function of irradiation time for [BMIM]BF4 and the IL-based nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01%. This temperature enhancement represents the temperature differences between the fluid samples and ambient temperature during the irradiation time of 10800 s. As plotted in Fig. 7, the temperature enhancement for all samples exhibits a similar trend that rapidly rises up for the first 3000 s, gradually increases between 3000 s and 5000 s, and reaches a maximum and keeps it after 6000 s. This trend can be attributed to the facts that, the temperatures of the samples increases with the exposed time owing to their ability to convert light energy to heat, which increase in temperature leads to an enhancement in heat emission simultaneously. After the heat generation and the heat loss are in equilibrium, the samples keep almost constant temperatures (stagnation temperatures). Furthermore, it can be seen from Fig. 7 that the nanofluids not only exhibit sharper rise in temperature during the first 3000 s but also finally reaches higher stagnation temperatures, compared to the base liquid. It is revealed that the photo-thermal conversion performance of the IL has been enhanced by the addition of the carbon nanomterials. More
0.005% and 0.01%.
significantly, the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials reach different stagnation temperatures. Specifically, the stagnation temperatures of the nanofluids containing GNPs, SWCNTs and GE are 83.2 C, 94.8 C and 99.0 C at the loading of 0.005 wt%, and change to 93.5 C, 95.0 C and 103.5 C as the loading is increased to 0.01 wt%, respectively. For the GNPsdispersed nanofluids, a remarkable increase in stagnation temperature with mass fraction is observed. However, the stagnation temperatures of the SWCNTs-dispersed nanofluids keep almost the same with varying mass fractions, which could be attributed to the tangling of the SWCNTs especially at the high temperatures. Among the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials, the GEdispersed ones reach the highest stagnation temperatures even at the loading of as low as 0.05 wt%, indicating their excellent ability to convert light energy to heat.
Moreover, the photo-thermal conversion efficiency h of all the samples has been calculated according to the following formula:
h ¼ mcpðTs TiÞ GADt
(2)
where m and cp is the mass and specific heat of samples respectively, Ti is initial temperature, Ts is stagnation temperature, A is the top surface area of the receiver, G is heat flux of the incident solar, and Dt is the time exposed to solar radiation. In the current work, the average solar irradiation G is measured to be about 1001.35 W m 2 cp can be obtained from Fig. 5. Dt is set at the irradiation time of 10800 s (3 h). As displayed in Fig. 8, the photo-
thermal conversion efficiencies of the nanofluids are obviously higher than that of pure IL, revealing that the addition of carbon nanomaterials into the base liquid has the function of enhancing its photo-thermal conversion ability. This enhancement can be attributed to the superior thermal conductivity (Fig. 3) and radiative property (Fig. 6) of the nanofluids over those of the base liquid. Besides, it is clearly shown that the GE-dispersed nanofuids possesses much higher photo-thermal conversion efficiency than the GNPs- and SWCNTs-dispersed ones. Under the same irradiation, the temperature rise rate and the stagnation temperature are mainly depended on the optical absorption property and internal heat transfer ability of fluid [45]. As shown in Figs. 3 and 6, the GEdispersed nanofluids possess the highest thermal conductivity and extinction coefficient among all the nanofluids, resulting in their highest stagnation temperatures and photo-thermal conversion efficiency. The excellent photo-thermal conversion performance makes the GE-dispersed nanofluids show great potential for use as a kind of high-performance HTFs for DASCs.

sections.heading: 3.4. Stability of nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials
sections.text: Fig. 9 displays the photographs of the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01% before and after having been storing for one month. All the as-prepared Ionanofluids are black and have been well dispersed. After one month, no sedimentations have been observed on the bottoms of the bottles containing the nanofluids, implying that the nanofluids containing the carbon nanomaterials can maintain stable for about one month, even no surfactants have been added into them during the preparation. Furthermore, it has been reported that the thermal conductivity of nanofluids could be directly influenced by the particle aggregation and sedimentation [46]. Therefore, the dispersion stability of the Ionanofluids has been further evaluated by monitoring their thermal conductivity for 14 days. Fig. 10 shows the variations of thermal conductivity with time for the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials at different loadings. It can be seen that all the samples show no obvious changes in thermal conductivity with time, suggesting that the nanofluids containing the three kinds of carbon nanomaterials possess good dispersion stability.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Three kinds of carbon nanomaterials with different morphologies, namely, zero-dimensional GNPs, one-dimensional SWCNTs and two-dimensional GE, were dispersed into [BMIM]BF4 to prepare the IL-based nanofluids with mass fractions of 0.005% and 0.01%, respectively. The thermo-physical properties (thermal conductivity, viscosity and specific heat) of [BMIM]BF4 and the [BMIM] BF4-based nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials
ispersed ones; B1eB3 refers to 0.01 wt% GNPs-, SWCNTs- and GE-dispersed ones).
were experimentally investigated. The thermal conductivity of the nanofluids has been obviously increased by the addition of the carbon nanomaterials as compared to the base liquid, and the enhancement ratios varied with the dispersed carbon nanomaterial with different morphologies. The thermal conductivity enhancement ratios of the SWCNTs-dispersed nanofluids are higher than those of the GNPs-dispersed ones, but lower than those of the GEdispersed ones at the same loadings. Compared to the IL, all the nanofluids exhibit a reduction in viscosity owing to the lubrication originated from the carbon nanomaterials, and the reduction ratios varied with different types of carbon nanomaterials dispersed. The viscosity of [BMIM]BF4 and all the nanofluid greatly decreases with the increase in temperature until it finally reaches around 5 cp at 150 C. The specific heat values of the nanofluids were slightly lower than those of the base IL at the same temperatures, and the reductions were different with different types of nanomaterials dispersed. It is revealed that the morphology factor of carbon nanomaterials should be a key role in the thermo-physical properties of the nanofluids.
The transmission spectra of [BMIM]BF4 and the IL-based nanofluids were measured, which revealed that the optical properties of the nanofluids have been greatly enhanced due to the introduction of the carbon nanomaterials. Among the nanofluids containing the three kinds of carbon nanomaterials, the GE-dispersed ones exhibit the highest extinction coefficients, reaching an extinction coefficient of as high as around 10 cm 1 at a loading of 0.01%. The photothermal conversion performance of [BMIM]BF4 and the nanofluids were assessed under a solar simulator. The nanofluids containing the carbon nanomaterials exhibit sharper rise in temperature and reaches higher stagnation temperatures as compared to the base liquid, indicating that the photo-thermal conversion performance of the IL has been enhanced by the addition of the carbon nanomterials. Among the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials, the GE-dispersed ones exhibited the highest photothermal conversion efficiency, indicating their excellent ability to convert light energy to heat, which can be ascribed to their highest thermal conductivity enhancement ratio along with extinction coefficient. The superiorities in thermal conductivity, optical property and photo-thermal conversion efficiency make the GEdispersed nanofluids show great potential for use as highperformance HTFs in solar thermal applications such as working fluids for DASCs.

Different from the commonly used surface-based solar collectors, DASCs, where working fluids directly absorb solar radiation, exhibit reduced heat loss by minimizing temperature differences between the absorber and the fluid, thus promising increased performance [17].

The researchers from Arizona State University [26,27] reported that a theoretical nanofluid enhancement in efficiency of up to 10% could be achieved by the nanofluid-based DASCs as compared to surface-based collectors.

[28] presented that receiver-side efficiencies are predicted to exceed 35% when the nanofluid-based DASCs are coupled to a power cycle and optimized with respect to the optical thickness and solar exposure time.

[29] obtained extinction coefficients of the nanofluids by both model predictions and spectroscopic measurements and found that over 95% of incoming sunlight can be absorbed by the nanofluids with extremely low nanoparticle volume fractions.

Furthermore, in view of the dual role of the nanofluids used in DASCs, it is rational that the thermo-physical and radiative properties of nanofluids determine their ability to convert light energy to heat, all of which are supposed to play a key role in establishing the collecting efficiency of the nanofluid-based DASCs [11].

Furthermore, our previous work [36] demonstrated that, when the pure and carbon-coated Ni nanoparticles with the same average sizes of 40 nmwere dispersed into the same base liquid at the same loading, respectively, the obtained nanofluid containing the carbon-coated Ni nanoparticles exhibited better radiative property than the un-coated Ni nanoparticles dispersed one, revealing that carbon coated on the surfaces of Ni nanoparticles enhanced the radiative property of the nanofluid containing them.

metadata.abstractText: Graphite nanoparticles (GNPs), single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and graphene (GE) were dispersed into an ionic liquid (IL) to prepare nanofluids at different mass fractions, respectively. The thermo-physical characteristics, radiative properties, and photo-thermal conversion performance of the IL-based nanofluids containing the carbon nanomaterials with different morphologies were investigated in details. It is shown that all the nanofluids exhibit an increase in thermal conductivity and a decrease in viscosity as composed with the base liquid, and the enhancement and reduction ratios varied with their morphologies. The GE-dispersed nanofluids exhibit the highest thermal conductivity enhancement ratios as compared to the GNPsand SWCNTs-dispersed ones at the same mass fractions. Among the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials, the GE-dispersed nanofluids show the lowest transmittance and possess the highest extinction coefficients. It is revealed that the photo-thermal conversion performance of the IL has been enhanced by the addition of the carbon nanomterials, and the GE-dispersed nanofluids exhibit the highest photo-thermal conversion efficiency among the nanofluids containing different carbon nanomaterials. The superiorities in thermal conductivity, optical property and photothermal conversion efficiency make the GE-dispersed nanofluids show great potential for use as highperformance HTFs in solar thermal systems such as working fluids for DASCs. © 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
